case_vignette: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in his mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year at high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of his oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have painful lesions in my mouth that have been there for four days.
Do you have any similar lesions or rashes on other parts of your body?
No, I do not have any lesions on my genitals or anus.
Have you noticed any blisters or ulcers elsewhere on your skin, like on your hands or face?
No, I have only noticed the lesions in my mouth.
Do you have any other symptoms such as fever, joint pain, or eye irritation?
No, I don't have any other symptoms like fever, joint pain, or eye irritation.
Have you experienced any recent stress or illness before these symptoms appeared?
Yes, I have been very stressed over the past month because I am approaching my senior year at high school.
Do you have a history of similar mouth lesions in the past?
Yes, I have had similar lesions in my mouth twice in the past year.
Final Diagnosis: Recurrent Aphthous Stomatitis (Canker Sores)
